reviewText:
In short, Strike Suit Infinity is an arcade style space shooter in which the player undertakes a series of missions to increase his score and battling with others on rankings on the games very own leaderboards. Unlike the Heroes of the Fleet DLC for the original Strike Suit Zero from 2013, the player now has the chance to earn credits and to build up a fleet of his own that will support him over the course of the game.

There is a total of 18 missions (rounds). You begin on the first round & move straight on to the next. Between rounds you will be able to build up your fleet, unlock Strike Suit Upgrades by solving bonus objectives & selecting the Loadout of Missiles for use. If your Suit gets destroyed during a round you lose the game and your accumulated score gets uploaded to the leaderboards.

The game saves your progress if you quit or the game crashes in the middle of a round. The downside to this is that it will deactivate your reached scored from being uploaded to the leaderboard. If you want to have your score uploaded, you either have to die during a mission or play through all 18 rounds in one sitting.

On the contrary, you can quit your game in the middle of a round, which automatically saves earned credits, ship upgrades, fleet setup. This allows you to continue next time exactly where you left of and play at your leisure, getting familiar with the game or to try out different setups.

Playing through all the rounds in one sitting is a difficult task that requires knowledge about each rounds adversary, perfect planning of your Fleet beforehand as well as a large amount of experience with the games controls & sometimes chaotic, rough but fun space combat.

If you love to compete against others, entertaining space combat simulations & a great challenge then go ahead and give Strike Suit Infinity or the original Strike Suit Directors Cut a try. Then let’s be honest there, there aren’t many good 6DOF games out there at the moment and Strike Suit belongs to the absolute best to play right now.

reviewText:
When I first considered getting this game it was for a few things:
1. Combat looked quite similar to a space MMO I used to play and love (I knew this was not an MMO-style game, but the gamePLAY is what I am feeling similar) and it also appeared very skill-based (aside from the mech-like form)
2. What seemed like smooth flight controls and the sort
3. Upgradeability (which was my biggest inclination to purchase this game, as I love games in which they give you the option to stat-build, pick skillsets, as well as upgrade items/abilities/etc.)

HOWEVER, when I start playing this game, the feel of the game is very clunky and not as smooth as it makes itself out to look (holding S to reduce speed actually tries to make you go reverse, giving you poor camera control when attempting to slow down). Also, when in combat, the gameplay is more like your average airplane shooting sort-of game where you must lead your lasers (which I don't mind much, aside for it being in a space combat game) and the missile lock-on is very slow and unappeasing (very bland missile animation).

I summed up just a few small things right there, but to address the biggest thing that pulled me in, massively disappointing me in the end was the customization and ability to upgrade your ships.

Based on my reading, I knew there would only be 3 ships to choose from, that's fine, but when the only way you can upgrade your ships is by destroying a freighter in order to obtain a predetermined upgrade instead of providing a skill point or whatnot, greatly limiting your creativity or playstyle. Also, you gain points every set of waves. What do you use these points for? You use them to hire small fleets of allies and rank up their AI. You gain points at the end of each set of waves based on how many allies survived, then they VANISH. Your allies do not stick with you through the sets of waves, only for ONE SET. After selecting your allies to come with you and whether you want to upgrade their AI, you get to pick your primary and secondary weapons... HOORAY!!! But... You are unable to pick different lasers than the base selection given, and you can only swap one of your missle slots for the other missile you already have equipped and naught else. This customization may improve later on, but for the first ship available, that is all you have access to.

Also, the mech form along with auto-aim (hold left-shift to snap to the next target once your current target dies + turn to face them!) is so overpowering, I just run into a mob of enemies, activate, hold shift, and shoot my primaries to end up with a combo of 8 enemy ships killed or whatnot. The mass-missile aiming makes close to no sense that I have no clue what ships it's locked on to nor do I have any idea why it's possible to lock on to the same ship more than 3-4 times (around 15 or so locks is the limit).

The map size is larger than needed, at least for earlier rounds. It doesn't give you enough time to fly between objective targets (like freighters so you can get upgrades), and if you do it takes off 50-70% of the time you have, leaving you with too little time to kill the enemy wave in time for the multiplier bonus (this is not helped when the enemies spawn on all 4 cardinal direction entrances).

The gameplay is very flashy, and it builds itself up a lot. I wasn't expecting much, but I got less than I wanted and I am generally displeased with the way this game has turned out to be.

On the upside, the game looks very nice and follows through with being just wave after wave of combat. If that's what you're looking for, then go ahead and get it, if not, look elsewhere.

All the best bits from Strike Suit Zero (the space combat, transforming flight suits, weaponry, enemy variety, and stunning backdrops) packed into a wave-based score attack game.

Kill stuff, get money, buy more stuff.  Upgrade your accompanying fleet.  Buy bigger ships.  Use whatever means suit your combat style.  Heavy hitters will love the Marauder class.  Fast, rapid offense strikers will enjoy the light-armoured Raptor (its shotgun weapon makes short work of mounted cannons).  Then there is the old classic, the standard issue strike suit.

Something for everyone and potentially dozens of hours of entertainment.  Relieve your day stress by taking it out on those pesky colonials.

it's like Galaga on steroids\n10/10

Like Strike Suit Zero, Strike Suit Infinity is a fast-paced space combat game, similar to Freespace and Freelancer, with gameplay that requires speed, control, and timing similar to typical fighting games. The difference is, it's more of an arcade-style game where you basically fight wave after wave as you stack up points to boost your score.

This is a really fun game - reminds me of Omega Boost for the PS1. It's quite difficult, though - I wish there was a difficulty slider so I could complete the game on Easy first while getting familiar with the controls and the best-practice methods.\n

Solid mechanics and really great gameplay. This whole game comes together and it’s simply a great work of art. Dog fights, strike mode, blasting capital ships, and getting high scores. Doing this and having a blast is what it’s all about. This fills the void of my desire for Ace Combat for PCs (I’m talking about a good Ace Combat mind you).

Infinity is an interesting score attack and reinforcement management version of Strike Suit Zero. Strike Suit Zero’s campaign is awesome and feels great, but we have no control over anything but our own ship. In Infinity we can allocate what kind of reinforcements we’ll be using in certain rounds and there’s a bigger incentive to try and save your teammates. Overall Infinity is fun and much tougher than Zero by far. A good challenge for those who’ve graduated from Zero.
Good enough to tide me over until they release Strike Suit Zero Two: More Strike Suiting.

Unfortunately, the tutorial fell short. For those that are new to flying action games, you will be left with a lot of things to figure out. On top of the fact that you will spend a large amount of time to learn basic flying mechanic, you will have to deal with very fast pace action and lots of small details on the battlefield like: incoming missles, incoming mines, shield level, lock-on timer, EMP timer, dodging, aiming with different guns that have different fire-rate, etc. All the details can be overwhelming for those new to the genre.

The interface tries to be straight forward so you can enter the action quickly. But. This means that you can easily be confused of what the interface try to convey. They gave a list of ships you will encounter each level. Okay? Can I get the stats of each ship to plan out what I want to do? They gave you ship upgrade screen. Yet they did not mention that you don't interact with the upgrades on the screen, the only time you get upgrades is when you kill certain optional ships in the actual level.  The screen is there to review the upgrades you own.  They gave you a fleet information screen so you can get allies and upgrade your fleet. Yet they do not give enough information for the upgrades and ships so you can make good decision. I still don't know the damage, durability, and abilities the different ships have. and I definitely do not know the detail of what upgrading ship crew will do to my fleet.

I suggest this game to those who are used to the genre or those who are willing to explore the game until they master the basics. The game really get interesting once you get the details out of the way.

A fun little arcade game! This game has you piloting a Strike Suit against waves of enemies in a space simulation, ranking you on how well you do, how many of your allies stay alive, and the like. In all the game has 18 segments, each comprised of a different number of waves. You can jump into any segment you've progressed to, or run through linearly until you explode. Combat and flight feel nice and solid, with missiles and guns to use and a detailed lock-on system, a lead-target indicator, and the ability to switch between equipped weapon sets.

This game adds more to that, however, by including a system called strike mode. As you kill enemies and complete objectives, you'll fill a bar which powers strike mode. You can switch over at any time you have some in the bar, as far as I can tell, and turn into a gundam-style slaughterhouse of awesome. Even in this mode, kills will still extend your strike suit time, and attacks made cost tiny chunks of it. It feels very fun to switch into strike mode, paint locks on a squad of enemies, sidestep a missile, and obliterate all of them in a swarm of death-dealing return missiles.

The game is difficult, with a regenerating shield you'll loose often if you arn't careful, and a health bar that takes damage when your shields can't. Over time, if you go after the optional enemy frigates that warp in, you can unlock upgrades, new weapons to use, and a limited number of ships.

Still, it's a fun, face-paced space combat game, very worth it for the price.

Strike Suit Infinity does a great job recreating the intense moments of classic space combat sims (TIE Fighter, Freesapce 2) in a bite-sized format that's good for picking up a few minutes or rounds at a time.  There's no plot to hook on to, just guns, missiles and the rush of your ship's afterburners as you weave through your enemy's flak cannons.  If you're a fan of space combat games, you can't go wrong for five bucks.  For two bucks on a Steam sale, you'd be stupid not to buy it.

Besides, it's not like there's anything else to play in this dead genre until Star Citizen comes out.  At least this is a good title.

All that said, I still prefer Freespace Open (FS2 enhanced) as the undisputed KING of space combat.  While there's no anime-inspired mech suits, the ships controls feel more intimate, the graphics are better, the explosions are bigger, and the plot is actually gripping--surprises work, your heart sinks at the enemy's doings, you hate Command's intelligence".  Better full sized game in general.

But Strike Suit Infinity isn't a full sized game.  It's an indie arcade game for short consumption

The main problem would be the controls, I spent half of my time trying to make the damn craft fly straight. The other half was trying to dodge. The acceleration and combat aspects feel similar to a free roam Starfox, but the target reticle is near impossible to control. The enemies are too shifty to actually line up a shot making the dogfights feel chaotic at best. Mostly the missions consist of mayhem. If the aiming worked more like a first person shooter, I wouldn't have a problem with this game at all. But the game instead works on a scrolling system. If your crosshairs are even the slightest off centered, then the ship will move in that direction rapidly, so you constantly have to find the center of the screen to fly straight. Keep in mind that I had the game sensitivity and my mouse sensitivity set to the lowest possible setting. This game should take a page from the Tachyon games in my opinion. To sum up, this is a gorgeous game with an immersive atmosphere that put me in the cockpit, but the controls really made me dispise massive dogfights. Worth a try if you find it on sale.

My recomendation for this game is provisional. While the game is absolutely gorgeous from its settings to music, it suffers from a few fatal flaws that made it hard for me to enjoy. The main problem would be the controls, I spent half of my time trying to make the damn craft fly straight. The other half was trying to dodge. The acceleration and combat aspects feel similar to a free roam Starfox, but the target reticle is near impossible to control. The enemies are too shifty to actually line up a shot making the dogfights feel chaotic at best. Mostly the missions consist of mayhem. If the aiming worked more like a first person shooter, I wouldn't have a problem with this game at all. But the game instead works on a scrolling system. If your crosshairs are even the slightest off centered, then the ship will move in that direction rapidly, so you constantly have to find the center of the screen to fly straight. Keep in mind that I had the game sensitivity and my mouse sensitivity set to the lowest possible setting. This game should take a page from the Tachyon games in my opinion. To sum up, this is a gorgeous game with an immersive atmosphere that put me in the cockpit, but the controls really made me dispise massive dogfights. Worth a try if you find it on sale.

Ironically, Strike Suit Infinity has a limited opportunity for fun, but does a good job while it lasts.

The main menu prompts you to take a look at Strike Suit Zero for more space dog fight action! Strike Suit infinity, I reckon, is infinitely more fun than Strike Suit Zero. These reasons I will examine in my Strike Suit Zero review, but the reasons Infinity stands above its fellow brother game I will show to you now.

For one thing, Infinity is strictly a wave-based space combat game. There's no story, no real context, no different maps. You pick your space suit, your guns, your friends, and then test your luck in the open field.

It's surreal to see the potential of the Strike Suit series without Zero's terrible story and terrible game saving functionality. SS Infinity ends each level with the last wave, and then you choose whether to keep fighting or not.

Starting a mission restarts the points collected thus far, which buy allies and suit level ups. I don't understand why you cant just have a save game screen to solve this issue of continuity. What if two people want to play the game and have separate stats without forfeiting their progress?

Gameplay is wonderful, if not tiring due to the heavy loading screens in between each and every battle. It's about a five minute wait, which feels like a waste of time if not just straight up poor design. It just tire sout the audience, then you'd much rather shut the game off than try for the fourth time to kill the enemy space battleship


Good game, but it feels like the gaming is milked out of the player.
It's still better than Strike Suit Zero, simply for having fewer hassles, fewer game crashes, slightly more sensible save game options, and lack of a terrible story.
Still, nothing new is added, so Infinity feels more like a clean up job to make Zero more of a practical arcade shooter.
Strike Suit Infinity performs its gameplay admirably, but this shiny spot is only contrasted by all the problems surrounding it.
